 The evidence is to the contrary:
 
 Survey Finds Conservative Churches Growing, Liberal Ones Declining
 
 Perhaps the only surprise in a recent survey of churches and other religious bodies in America was that anyone was surprised at the results.
 
 Conservative churches in the U.S., including the Roman Catholic and Mormon churches as well as evangelical and charismatic denominations, are growing fastest, while the "mainline" Protestant churches, which are increasingly liberal, have seen continuing declines in their membership. The findings were released in September in a report titled "Religious Congregations & Membership in the United States: 2000," which was sponsored by the Association of Statisticians of American Religious Bodies (ASARB) and published by the Catholic-affiliated Glenmary Research Center of Nashville. 
 
 "I was astounded to see that by and large the growing churches are those that we ordinarily call conservative," Glenmary's director Ken Sanchagrin told the New York Times. "And when I looked at those that were declining, most were moderate or liberal churches. And the more liberal the denomination, the more they were losing."
 
 Some of the reported explanations for why conservative churches are growing almost seemed contradictory. Sanchagrin described conservative churches as "demanding in some way?[they] expect you to come two or three times a week, or not wear lipstick, or dress in a certain way." But Bill Leonard, a professor of church history at North Carolina's Wake Forest University, said that "their worship services are user-friendly. You don't have to dress up. They put the words on the screen. There's fewer pipe organs and more guitars and drums." Rodney Stark, a sociologist on the west coast, believes the service schedules of some shrinking churches demand too much, saying, "the . . . fools who only have a service at 11:00 a.m. are going to miss the male football-watching crowd."
 
 Mark Tooley of the Institute for Religion and Democracy, which promotes evangelical renewal in the mainline denominations, focused on theology instead. "Liberal theology commits suicide by de-emphasizing the need for personal conversion," Tooley said. "For conservatives the main objective of the church is to evangelize."
 
 The Presbyterian Church (U.S.A.) is one of the denominations whose membership is declining, falling 12 percent in the last decade. Parker Williamson, editor of "The Presbyterian Layman," a conservative newspaper, thinks he knows why. "The Presbyterian Church (U.S.A.) leadership no longer knows what it believes. Who is Jesus Christ? . . . They were asked to declare in Louisville that 'Jesus Christ is Lord,' and they could not do it." Meanwhile, the smaller, more conservative Presbyterian Church in America grew 42 percent in the last ten years.
 
 Among the other churches losing members are the United Church of Christ (the first denomination to ordain open homosexuals), down 14 percent; the United Methodist Church, down 7 percent; the American Baptist Churches in the U.S.A., down 6 percent; the Episcopal Church, down 5 percent; and the Evangelical Lutheran Church in America, down 2 percent.
 
 The fastest growing of the major denominations were the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-Day Saints (also known as LDS or Mormons), which has an aggressive missionary program, up by 19.3%; the "Christian Church and Churches of Christ," up 18.6%; the Assemblies of God, a Pentecostal denomination, up 18.5%; and the Roman Catholic church (aided by 57 percent growth in the Hispanic population), up 16.2 percent.
 
 Among smaller denominations, significant growth in membership was reported by the Salvation Army (up 225%); the Evangelical Free Church (up 57%); Pentecostal Holiness churches (up 53%); the Wesleyan Church (up 47%); the Church of God based in Cleveland, Tennessee (up 40%), and the International Church of the Foursquare Gospel (up 36%).

 You responded to my observation that different religions' truth claims cancel each other out with your jar of beans analogy.
 
 I pointed out that the analogy was a poor one. 'How many beans are in this jar?' is a closed question, with one objective answer. If there are as many guesses as there are beans, and they are all different, one must be correct.

[It is noteworthy that there is a dearth of religions that believe in a malevolent god. Because of this, the probability that one guess is correct may not be approaching unity, as the number of guesses increases.]
 
 There is an objective truth about god (assuming one buys classical logic), just as there is an objective answer to the number of beans. That is (well formed) truth claims are either true or false. That we cannot know whether claims are true or false is immaterial; they are either true or false nonetheless.
 
 The notion that contradictory claims regarding the same issue "cancel" each other out is wrong. The (well-formed) claims "2+2 is 4" and "2+2 is not 4" don't cancel each other out. They aren't both wrong. In fact in the case of a statement and its negation, one statement is correct. As before, you wouldn't want "the notional christian god does not exist" to be cancelled out by "the notional christian god does exist". 
 
 
 This is not a good analogy with the questions asked and answered by religions, which are open, and which refer to concepts and entities whose real-world existence is itself the subject of those religions' speculations. 

 Well, I don't know what you mean by open. There is an objective truth about the condition of god. Possibly you may be getting confused about truth versus knowledge. Yes, religious claims, and anti-religious claims, are speculations. That does not mean that the claims are neither true nor false. Each (well formed) claim is either true of false. Just as each guess at the number beans is true or false. That we can't know whether a religious claim (or anti-religious claim) is true (or false) is immaterial. The claims are still not canceling each other out.
 
 
 
 Christianity's truth claim that Jesus was the son of god is contradicted by Islam's truth claim that he was just another prophet. Judaism's truth claim that there exists a single patriarchal deity is contradicted by polytheisms with multiple male and female deities. No amount of counter-assertion can bury the fact that the world's religions, extant and extinct, make or have made truth claims that cancel each other out. 

 Once again, "2+2 is 4" doesn't "cancel" out "2+2 is not 4". I believe you are making some kind of circumstantial fallacy.
